ADVANCING LOCAL CAPACITY FOR HEALTH EFFECTS FROM HEAT, AIR QUALITY, AND EXTREME EVENTS - CONNECTICUT DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH NATIONAL CENTER FOR ENVIRONMENT AND HEALTH: BUILDING RESILIENCE AGAINST CLIMATE EFFECTS: IMPLEMENTING AND EVALUATING ADAPTATION STRATEGIES THAT PROTECT AND PROMOTE HUMAN HEALTH CDC-RFA-EH21-2101 06/18/2021PROJECT ABSTRACT CHANGES TO CONNECTICUT?S CLIMATE POSE SPECIFIC RISKS TO PUBLIC HEALTH. EXTREME WEATHER EVENTS THREATEN CONNECTICUT?S MOST VULNERABLE POPULATIONS, WHICH IS REFLECTED IN CONNECTICUT?S SURVEILLANCE DATA. CONNECTICUT FACES SIGNIFICANT CLIMATE CHANGE IMPACTS SUCH AS INCREASING TEMPERATURES, IMPAIRED AIR QUALITY, FREQUENCY AND INTENSITY OF HEAT WAVES, HEAVY PRECIPITATION, AND FLOODING. URBANIZATION, INTENSE COASTAL DEVELOPMENT, INCREASED FLOODING FROM SEA LEVEL RISE AND STORM SURGE, AND HISTORIC AND ONGOING SOCIAL INEQUITIES AMPLIFY VULNERABILITIES TO EXTREME EVENTS. THE DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH (DPH) WILL IDENTIFY VULNERABLE POPULATIONS BY USING SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH AND APPLY THE BRACE FRAMEWORK AS PART OF OUR STRATEGY TO IMPROVE EQUALITY. OUR WORK UNDER THE BRACE FRAMEWORK IS DESIGNED TO ENHANCE DPH?S CAPACITY TO MITIGATE HEALTH THREATS OF CLIMATE ON OUR MOST VULNERABLE POPULATIONS BY RESPONDING TO BOTH IMMEDIATE AND FUTURE HEALTH RISKS. OUR FIRST PRIORITY ACTION WILL BE TO DESIGNATE A CLIMATE COORDINATOR TO WORK WITHIN DPH TO BEGIN BUILDING A PUBLIC HEALTH CLIMATE CHANGE PROGRAM THAT WILL LEVERAGE THE RESOURCES AND EXPERIENCES OF KEY PARTNERS IN THE REGION THAT INCLUDE YALE UNIVERSITY AND THE UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT, INCLUDING THE CONNECTICUT INSTITUTE FOR RESILIENCE AND CLIMATE. THESE PARTNERS WILL HELP DPH ACHIEVE ITS PROJECT OBJECTIVES, WHILE DPH?S CAPACITY IS ENHANCED TO PROACTIVELY ADDRESS ADDITIONAL PUBLIC HEALTH CHALLENGES FROM CLIMATE EFFECTS INCLUDING DROUGHTS, FLOODING, AND CLIMATE EFFECTS ON OUTDOOR WORKERS.   THE IMMEDIATE PROJECT GOALS INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING:? DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT AN EDUCATIONAL PROGRAM FOR TEACHERS, SCHOOL NURSES, AND OTHER SCHOOL PERSONNEL IN SOC IALLY VULNERABLE COMMUNITIES TO REDUCE STUDENT EXPOSURE TO EXTREME HEAT AND OZONE EVENTS? DEVELOP GUIDANCE FOR LOCAL HEAT AND AIR QUALITY RESPONSE PLANS (INCLUDING ALERTS AND COMMUNICATION STRATEGIES) AND SUPPORT LOCAL IMPLEMENTATION THROUGH TRAININGS AND CAPACITY BUILDING (FACILITATION OF COMMUNITY ACCESS: SERVICE ACCESS).THESE EFFORTS ALSO SEEK TO INCREASE THE SOCIAL CAPITAL AND SHARED KNOWLEDGE AMONG KEY COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS FOR A MORE RESILIENT PUBLIC HEALTH SYSTEM. BY WORKING WITH STAKEHOLDERS AND OUR PARTNERS, DPH HAS THE CAPACITY TO MEET THESE GOALS, WHICH IT WILL DO BY FOLLOWING THE BRACE FRAMEWORK REFINED AND IMPROVED BASED ON INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL EVALUATION.

SAN FRANCISCO DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH CLIMATE AND HEALTH PROGRAM ACTIONS TO REDUCE THE DISPROPORTIONATE IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE - SINCE 2013, THE SAN FRANCISCO DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH?S CLIMATE AND HEALTH PROGRAM HAS WORKED TO ADDRESS THE LOCAL HEALTH IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE THROUGH RESEARCH AND ASSESSMENTS, MAPS AND DATA TOOLS, OUTREACH AND ENGAGEMENT, AND WORKING INTERDEPARTMENTALLY TO BRING A HEALTH PERSPECTIVE TO CITYWIDE CLIMATE ADAPTATION ACTIVITIES. IN SAN FRANCISCO, CLIMATE CHANGE MEANS EXTREME TEMPERATURES, SEA LEVEL RISE AND EXTREME STORMS, WILDFIRES AND AIR POLLUTION?AND THESE EVENTS HAVE SIGNIFICANT, CASCADING, AND COMPOUNDING IMPACTS ON PUBLIC HEALTH. THESE HEALTH IMPACTS ARE NOT EVENLY DISTRIBUTED AND THE COMMUNITIES WHO CARRY THE HEAVIEST HEALTH BURDEN ARE THE ONES MOST EXPOSED, MOST SENSITIVITY, AND WITH THE LEAST ACCESS TO THE ECONOMIC, SOCIAL, AND POLITICAL RESOURCES TO ADAPT. LOCAL HEALTH DEPARTMENTS ARE UNIQUELY POSITIONED TO WORK ACROSS SECTORS TO IDENTIFY, IMPLEMENT, AND IMPROVE EQUITABLE CLIMATE ACTIONS THROUGH:?ACTING AS A FIRST-POINT-OF-CONTACT TO MANY OF THE MOST IMPACTED COMMUNITIES REGULAR HEALTH CARE SERVICES AND OUTREACH ACTIVITIES.?USING HOSPITALIZATION, EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT, AND SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH DATA TO MEASURE HEALTH BURDEN AND EVALUATE INTERVENTIONS BASED ON THESE MEASURES. ?IDENTIFYING AND SUPPORTING INTERVENTIONS WITH CLIMATE HEALTH CO-BENEFITS.?DEVELOPING OUTREACH, ENGAGEMENT, AND INVOLVEMENT STRATEGIES TO SUPPORT COMMUNITIES TO BUILD CAPACITY TO PREPARE FOR AND RESPOND TO CLIMATE CHANGE-RELATED HAZARDS.?USING QUALITATIVE AND QUANTITATIVE RESEARCH TO DEVELOP VULNERABILITY ASSESSMENTS.IN THIS APPLICATION, THE CLIMATE AND HEALTH PROGRAM WILL PROPOSE SPECIFIC AND MEASURABLE ACTIONS TO ADDRESS THE HEALTH IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE, AND ESPECIALLY CLIMATE CHANGE?S DISPROPORTIONATE IMPACT ON SAN FRANCISCO?S VULNERABLE COMMUNITIES. THE CLIMATE AND HEALTH PROGRAM IS APPLYING FOR BOTH THE CORE COMPONENT AND COMPONENT-A. THESE ACTIONS WILL USE THE BRACE FRAMEWORK TO ENHANCE CLIMATE HEALTH LEADERSHIP, EXPAND STAKEHOLDER RELATIONS HIPS, COMPILE EVIDENCE AND BEST PRACTICES TO DEVELOP ADAPTATION PLANS, BUILD RESILIENCE THROUGH THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THOSE ADAPTATION PLANS, AND EVALUATE AND DISSEMINATE BEST PRACTICES. SPECIFICALLY, THE CLIMATE AND HEALTH PROGRAM WILL PROPOSE ACTIVITIES TO EXPAND THE ROLE OF LOCAL HEALTH DEPARTMENTS TO FACILITATE LARGE INTERSECTORAL CLIMATE ADAPTATION PROCESSES THAT BRINGS TOGETHER CITY DEPARTMENTS, COMMUNITY-BASED ORGANIZATIONS, REGIONAL NETWORKS, AND ACADEMIC PARTNERS. THE HEAT AND AIR QUALITY RESILIENCE PROJECT (HAQR) REPRESENTS AN INNOVATIVE APPROACH TO COORDINATE THE IDENTIFICATION, IMPLEMENTATION, AND EVALUATION OF MEDIUM-TO-LONG-RANGE RESILIENCE ACTIONS. HAQR IS A CLIMATE AND HEALTH ADAPTATION IDENTIFIED IN THE CORE COMPONENT AND COMPONENT A. THE EXPANDED COMPONENT-A HAQR INCLUDES EXPANDED RESEARCH, CBO-SUPPORT, OUTREACH AND ENGAGEMENT, AND EVALUATION INITIATIVES. AS ONE OF THE TWO LOCAL HEALTH DEPARTMENTS TO RECEIVE DIRECT FUNDING THROUGH THE CDC CLIMATE RESILIENT STATES AND CITIES INITIATIVE BUILDING RESILIENCE AGAINST CLIMATE EFFECTS GRANT RFA-EH16-1606, THE SAN FRANCISCO CLIMATE AND HEALTH PROGRAM HAS THE RESPONSIBILITY TO USE THIS CAPACITY TO TRAIN OTHER LOCAL HEALTH DEPARTMENTS. THIS APPLICATION WILL PROPOSE ACTIONS TO WORK DIRECTLY WITH LHDS TO DISSEMINATE BEST PRACTICES AND OFFER OPPORTUNITIES TO SUPPORT THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THOSE BEST PRACTICES.

IMPLEMENTING AND EVALUATING ADAPTATION STRATEGIES THAT PROTECT AND PROMOTE HUMAN HEALTH IN WISCONSIN - THIS GRANT WILL IMPROVE THE CAPACITY OF THE WISCONSIN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH SERVICES TO RESPOND AND ADAPT TO CLIMATE-RELATED PUBLIC HEALTH IMPACTS ACROSS THE STATE WITH A FOCUS ON VULNERABLE POPULATIONS. THE STRATEGIES OUTLINED IN THIS GRANT WILL LEVERAGE EXISTING RESOURCES AND PARTNERSHIPS IN THE STATE TO IMPROVE HEALTH OUTCOMES RELATED TO EXTREME HEAT, AIR QUALITY, AND SEVERE WEATHER AND FLOODING. WISCONSIN?S CLIMATE HAS CHANGED SIGNIFICANTLY IN THE LAST CENTURY AND CHANGES ARE EXPECTED TO INTENSIFY, RESULTING IN WARMER TEMPERATURES, INCREASED FREQUENCY AND SEVERITY OF FLOOD EVENTS, AND EXACERBATE IMPAIRED AIR QUALITY.  TO INCREASE CORE CAPACITY AT THE CLIMATE AND HEALTH PROGRAM (WCHP), WE WILL ENHANCE PROGRAM INFRASTRUCTURE BY BUILDING INTERNAL CAPACITY, POSITIONING CLIMATE AND HEALTH AS A HIGH PRIORITY THROUGHOUT THE DEPARTMENT, AND PROVIDING LEADERSHIP BOTH WITHIN THE DEPARTMENT AND TO EXTERNAL PARTNERS. WE WILL DETERMINE EVIDENCED-BASED BEST PRACTICES TO HELP OUR PARTNERS DEVELOP CLIMATE ADAPTATION PLANS RELATED TO EXTREME WEATHER EVENTS, HEAT, AND IMPAIRED AIR QUALITY. STRATEGIES INCLUDE IMPROVEMENT AND EXPANDED IMPLEMENTATION OF THE FLOOD RESILIENCE SCORECARD, THE DEVELOPMENT OF A HEAT HEALTH WARNING SYSTEM FOR VULNERABLE AREAS OF THE STATE, AND IMPROVING AIR QUALITY MONITORING AND COMMUNICATION. FUNDING WILL ENHANCE OUR ABILITY TO EVALUATE EACH OF THE STRATEGIES AND SHARE PROGRAM ACTIVITIES WITH THE PUBLIC AND OUR PARTNERS.  IN ADDITION TO INCREASING THE CORE CAPACITY OF OUR PROGRAM, FUNDING WILL FURTHER ENHANCE OUR ABILITY TO EXPAND IMPLEMENTATION AND EVALUATION OF CORE ADAPTATION STRATEGIES. WE WILL ACHIEVE THIS THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT OF GRANTS FOR COMMUNITIES TO IMPLEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS FROM THE FLOOD RESILIENCE SCORECARD, AN ANTI-IDLING CAMPAIGN TO HELP IMPROVE AIR QUALITY IN VULNERABLE AREAS, AND EXPANDING PARTNERSHIPS TO ADDRESS HEALTH EQUITY RELATED TO CLIMATE CHANGE.  CLIMATE MITIGATION ACTIVITIES INCLUDE THE REDUCTION OF GREEN HOUSE GAS EMISSIONS AND EXPANDING THE USE OF ENVIRONMENTALLY SOUND PROGRAMS, WHICH MAY HAVE SPILLOVER BENEFITS FOR THE POPULATION. THIS GRANT WILL FURTHER HELP LEVERAGE RESOURCES AT THE UNIVERSITY OF WISCONSIN TO IDENTIFY HEALTH CO-BENEFITS RELATED TO CLIMATE MITIGATION. FUNDING WILL ALSO HELP DEVELOP COMPREHENSIVE COMMUNICATION STRATEGIES FOR THE HEALTH SECTOR TO PROMOTE KNOWLEDGE AND AWARENESS OF THE CO-BENEFITS OF ADAPTATION AND MITIGATION. ADEQUATE IMPLEMENTATION AND EVALUATION OF CLIMATE ADAPTATION STRATEGIES REQUIRES ROBUST DATA RESOURCES AND MANAGEMENT. FUNDING WILL ENHANCE OUR PROGRAM?S ABILITY TO MODERNIZE THE DATA COLLECTED THROUGH THE ADAPTATION STRATEGIES IDENTIFIED IN THIS GRANT. THIS MODERNIZATION INCLUDES THE USE OF NOVEL DATA SOURCES, SYNTHESIS OF DISPARATE DATA, IMPROVING INTERAGENCY SHARING, IMPLEMENTING CLOUD-BASED DATA STORAGE, ENHANCING DATA VISUALIZATION, AND DEVELOPING REAL-TIME DATA FOR PUBLIC HEALTH SURVEILLANCE. THE STRATEGIES MADE POSSIBLE THROUGH THIS FUNDING WILL TARGET VULNERABLE POPULATIONS AND ADDRESS HEALTH EQUITIES IN THE STATE RELATED TO CLIMATE CHANGE.

NYS BRACE: IMPLEMENTING ADAPTATIONS TO REDUCE THE HEALTH RISKS OF CLIMATE CHANGE - THE OVERARCHING PURPOSE OF THE NEW YORK STATE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH (NYSDOH)/HEALTH RESEARCH INC. (HRI) "NYS BRACE: IMPLEMENTING ADAPTATIONS TO REDUCE THE HEALTH RISKS OF CLIMATE CHANGE" PROJECT IS TO CONTINUE TO DEVELOP AND ENHANCE A CLIMATE AND HEALTH ADAPTATION PROGRAM ACROSS A FIVE-YEAR IMPLEMENTATION PERIOD. THROUGH THIS FUNDING, NYSDOH WILL CONTINUE WORK TO IDENTIFY, IMPLEMENT, AND EVALUATE ADAPTATION ACTIONS THAT ADDRESS EXTREME HEAT AND EXTREME WEATHER. THE ADAPTATION ACTIONS THAT ARE PROPOSED INCLUDE COLLABORATIONS WITH CDC-FUNDED AND NON-CDC-FUNDED AGENCIES AND ORGANIZATIONS THAT TARGET MARGINALIZED AND OTHER VULNERABLE POPULATIONS AND SEEK TO REDUCE HEALTH DISPARITIES AND BUILD HEALTH EQUITY.CLIMATE CHANGE IS AN IMPORTANT PRIORITY FOR NYS. IN JANUARY 2020, THE NYS CLIMATE LEADERSHIP AND COMMUNITY PROTECTION ACT (CLCPA) WENT INTO EFFECT. THE CLCPA?S GREENHOUSE GAS EMISSIONS (GHG) TARGETS ARE AMONG THE MOST RIGOROUS OF ANY MAJOR ECONOMY IN THE WORLD. NEW YORK STATE (NYS) HAS EXPERIENCED CONSISTENT WARMING OVER THE LAST CENTURY,. SUMMER TEMPERATURES HAVE INCREASED TO 2-3?F ABOVE HISTORICAL CLIMATE NORMS IN MOST AREAS OF THE STATE AND ARE PROJECTED TO INCREASE BY AS MUCH AS 10?F BY THE 2080S UNDER DIFFERENT CLIMATE SCENARIOS. MEAN ANNUAL PRECIPITATION HAS ALSO INCREASED AND BECOME MORE VARIABLE OVER THE LAST CENTURY. PRECIPITATION IS PROJECTED TO INCREASE BY UP TO 15% BY THE 2080S, AND IS EXPECTED TO OCCUR MOSTLY IN WINTER MONTHS.THE CORE PROPOSAL BUILDS UPON FINDINGS FROM PREVIOUS BRACE FUNDING CYCLES AND SEEKS TO IDENTIFY OPPORTUNITIES FOR NEW PARTNERSHIPS AND ACTIVITIES. KEY ACTIVITIES IN YEAR 1 WILL INCLUDE CONTINUED PARTICIPATION AND CONTRIBUTIONS IN THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THECLCPA; DEVELOPING A CLIMATE IMPACT COMPENDIUM WHICH UPDATES EXISTING RESOURCES THAT PROVIDE INFORMATION ABOUT CLIMATE IMPACTS, DATA AND INDICATORS, AND ADAPTIVE CAPACITY; EXTENDING WORK TO ENCOURAGE LOCAL HEALTH DEPARTMENTS TO CONSIDER THEIR CLIMATE ADAP TATION PRIORITIES; USING EVALUATION PLANS TO IMPROVE ADAPTATION ACTION; AND DEVELOPMENT AND MAINTENANCE OF CLIMATE HEALTH RISK PREVENTION MESSAGING AND OTHER COMMUNICATIONS. PROPOSED WORK WILL BUILD ON CURRENT PARTNERSHIPS WITH LOCAL HEALTH DEPARTMENTS, CLIMATOLOGISTS, AND NUMEROUS GOVERNMENTAL AND NON-GOVERNMENTAL PARTNERS AT THE LOCAL, STATE, AND NATIONAL LEVELS.THE COMPONENT A PROPOSAL BUILDS UPON ADAPTATION ACTIONS RELATING TO FLOOD VULNERABILITY THAT HAVE BEEN PROPOSED UNDER THE CORE PROPOSAL. WE PROPOSE TO LAUNCH A PILOT INITIATIVE TO IMPROVE THE SAFETY OF AT-RISK WELLS BY FUNDING THE PURCHASE OF NEW WELL CAPS, THE RAISING OF AT-RISK WELL HEADS, AND THE INSTALLATION OF UV DISINFECTION SYSTEMS. WE WILL PARTNER WITH LOCAL ORGANIZATIONS TO HOST TWO WORKSHOP SERIES TO PROMOTE STRATEGIC LONG-TERM SYSTEM RESILIENCY PLANNING. WE WILL CONDUCT A TARGETED OUTREACH AND EDUCATION SOCIAL MEDIA CAMPAIGN TO RAISE AWARENESS ABOUT FLOOD ZONES AND THE RISKS TO PRIVATE WELLS, AND TO DIRECT VIEWERS TO ADDITIONAL RESOURCES.THE COMPONENT B PROPOSAL SEEKS TO IMPLEMENT A HEALTH IMPACT ASSESSMENT OF TRANSPORTATION SECTOR CLIMATE MITIGATION POLICIES. DECREASES IN GHG AND CO-POLLUTANT EMISSIONS RESULTING FROM POLICY INITIATIVES TARGETING THE TRANSPORTATION SECTOR WILL IMPROVE PUBLIC HEALTH BY REDUCING RESPIRATORY, CARDIOVASCULAR OUTCOMES, AND PREMATURE MORTALITY. OUR PROPOSED PROJECT WILL USE NYS-SPECIFIC CRF WITH AN ESTIMATION OF PERCENTAGE IN EMISSIONS REDUCTIONS FROM SUCH A CHANGE IN POLICY TO ESTIMATE THE CO-BENEFITS OF SAVINGS ON HEALTH EXPENDITURE AND IMPROVED LIFE EXPECTANCY FROM AVOIDED MORBIDITY AND MORTALITY THROUGH SUCH MITIGATION EFFORTS. WE WILLIDENTIFY AREAS WHERE IMPROVEMENTS IN AIR QUALITY AND TARGETED INTERVENTIONS CAN RESULT IN GREATER ECONOMIC AND PUBLIC HEALTH BENEFIT FOR DISADVANTAGED COMMUNITIES. FINALLY, THESE RESULTS WILL BE DISSEMINATED TO STAKEHOLDERS SUCH AS COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS, NYSDEC AND NYSERDA TO SUP

OREGON CLIMATE AND HEALTH PROGRAM: BUILDING CAPACITY, SYSTEMS AND EVIDENCE FOR EQUITABLE CLIMATE RESILIENCE - THE OREGON HEALTH AUTHORITY (OHA) PROPOSES A PORTFOLIO OF COLLABORATIVE CLIMATE AND HEALTH PROJECTS THAT WILL REDUCE NEGATIVE HEALTH OUTCOMES, ESPECIALLY AMONG POPULATIONS MOST VULNERABLE TO THE ADVERSE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE IN OREGON. BUILDING UPON A DECADE OF IMPLEMENTING THE BRACE FRAMEWORK, THIS NEW COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WILL ALLOW OHA TO LEAD EVIDENCE-BASED INTERVENTIONS IN COLLABORATION WITH COMMUNITY PARTNERS ACROSS THE STATE. PROJECTS PROPOSED IN THE CORE COMPONENT INCLUDE PUBLISHING A NEW CLIMATE IMPACT COMPENDIUM, A JOINT NORTHWEST CLIMATE AND HEALTH INTERVENTION ASSESSMENT, AND AN UPDATED FIVE-YEAR COMMUNITY-DRIVEN CLIMATE AND HEALTH RESILIENCE PLAN. THE FUNDING WILL SUPPORT THE IMPLEMENTATION AND EVALUATION OF FOUR SPECIFIC ADAPTATION ACTIONS: THE HOME INTERVENTIONS AND TOOLS FOR CLIMATE HAZARDS (HITCH) PROJECT, THE CLIMATE AND HEALTH ADAPTATION EVALUATION SERVICES (CHAES) PROGRAM, THE CULTURALLY-RESPONSIVE CLIMATE AND HEALTH CURRICULA GRANT PROGRAM, AND THE INTERAGENCY OREGON CLIMATE EQUITY BLUEPRINT. OUR PROPOSED COMPONENT A ACTIVITIES WILL EXPAND UPON THIS WORK, BY IMPLEMENTING AND EVALUATING A NEW CLIMATE COMMUNITY CAPACITY PROGRAM (CCCP) THAT SUPPORTS COMMUNITIES DISPROPORTIONATELY AFFECTED BY CLIMATE-RELATED DISASTERS AND ADVANCES MORE EQUITABLE DISASTER RESILIENCE SYSTEMS AND POLICIES. ACTIVITIES PROPOSED IN COMPONENT B WILL INCREASE THE NUMBER OF CROSS-SECTOR CLIMATE MITIGATION INVESTMENTS THAT RESULT IN HEALTH CO-BENEFITS AT THE STATE AND LOCAL LEVELS. ACTIVITIES PROPOSED IN COMPONENT C WILL COMPLEMENT THE WORK PROPOSED IN THE OTHER COMPONENTS BY IMPROVING AND INCREASING CLIMATE AND HEALTH DATA TOOLS AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO INFORM CLIMATE ADAPTATION AND MITIGATION DECISION-MAKING BY OHA, OTHER STATE AGENCIES AND COMMUNITY PARTNERS. ALL PROPOSED ACTIVITIES ARE DESIGNED TO ALIGN WITH OUR THREE GUIDING PRINCIPLES OF BEING: EQUITY-CENTERED, COMMUNITY-DRIVEN, AND PREVENTION-ORIENTED.

BUILDING RESILIENCE TO HEAT AND AIR QUALITY IN SANTA CLARA COUNTY - THE COUNTY OF SANTA CLARA (CSC) SEEKS TO ADVANCE THE CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION?S BUILDING RESILIENCE AGAINST CLIMATE EFFECTS (BRACE) INITIATIVE BY PARTNERING INTERNALLY WITH COUNTY DEPARTMENTS AND EXTERNALLY WITH VULNERABLE COMMUNITIES TO BUILD CAPACITY FOR CLIMATE RESILIENCE. IN PARTNERSHIP WITH LOCAL COMMUNITY-BASED ORGANIZATIONS, THE CSC ALSO PLANS TO CO-DESIGN AND ENACT CLIMATE ADAPTATIONS AND COMMUNICATIONS IN RESPONSE TO ADVERSE CLIMATE-RELATED HEALTH OUTCOMES RESULTING FROM EXPOSURE TO EXTREME HEAT EVENTS AND IMPAIRED AIR QUALITY IN SANTA CLARA COUNTY (SCC).SCC IS THE 6TH LARGEST COUNTY IN CALIFORNIA, WITH A POPULATION OF APPROXIMATELY 1,927,852. THE COUNTY?S RACIAL/ETHNIC COMPOSITION IS 30.4% WHITE, 37.6% ASIAN, 25.0% HISPANIC, 2.4% AFRICAN AMERICAN, 0.2% NATIVE AMERICAN, AND 3.7% TWO OR MORE RACES. THE CITIES OF MORGAN HILL, GILROY, AND UNINCORPORATED AREAS OF SAN MARTIN, MOST OFTEN REFERRED TO AS SOUTH COUNTY, ARE THE MOST LIKELY REGION IN SCC TO EXPERIENCE THE MOST SIGNIFICANT NUMBER OF HIGH-HEAT DAYS COUPLED WITH THE LEAST RESOURCES AND LIVING CONDITIONS TO SUPPORT HEALTH AND WELL-BEING. RECOGNIZING THAT SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH INTERSECT WITH CLIMATE CHANGE TO CREATE HEALTH INEQUITIES, THE CSC WILL FOCUS BRACE ACTIVITIES INITIALLY ON PRIORITY POPULATIONS RESIDING WITHIN SOUTH COUNTY THAT ARE MOST VULNERABLE TO CLIMATE-RELATED ADVERSE HEALTH OUTCOME SUCH AS  YOUNG CHILDREN; OLDER ADULTS; LOW-INCOME PERSONS LIVING IN INADEQUATE HOUSING; PREGNANT WOMEN; OUTDOOR WORKERS; UNHOUSED; PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES; AND THOSE WITH ASTHMA, DIABETES, AND OTHER CHRONIC HEALTH CONDITIONS. IN FUTURE YEARS, THE CSC WILL BUILD ON THE SUCCESS OF THE SOUTH COUNTY-FOCUSED ACTIVITIES TO EXPAND AND SCALE CLIMATE ADAPTION ACTIVITIES TO OTHER PRIORITY GEOGRAPHIC AREAS AND AMONG OTHER POPULATIONS WHO ARE AT RISK FOR ADVERSE HEALTH OUTCOMES RELATED TO CLIMATE-RELATED EVENTS. THIS PROJECT WILL BUILD UPON LESSONS LEARNED FROM THE PAST AND PR ESENT COVID-19 RESPONSE AND WILL LEVERAGE AND EXPAND EXISTING PARTNERSHIPS TO ADDRESS CLIMATE IMPACTS IN SCC. THE BRACE TEAM WILL BE CO-LED BY THE CSC PUBLIC HEALTH DEPARTMENT AND THE OFFICE OF SUSTAINABILITY TO: 1) EMPOWER COUNTY EMPLOYEES ACROSS ALL DEPARTMENTS TO SERVE AS PRACTITIONERS AND CHAMPIONS FOR SUSTAINABILITY AND CLIMATE CHANGE; 2) CO-DEVELOP AND DISTRIBUTE RESILIENCE KITS THAT PROTECT HUMAN HEALTH FROM EXPOSURE TO EXTREME HEAT EVENTS AND IMPAIRED AIR QUALITY; 3) DEVELOP CROSS-SYSTEMS, MULTILINGUAL, CULTURALLY RELEVANT MEDIA COMMUNICATIONS ABOUT COOLING CENTERS AND OTHER CLIMATE IMPACT RESOURCES AVAILABLE IN SCC; 4) PARTNER WITH TRUSTED CBO?S TO CO-DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT A CLIMATE AND HEALTH RESILIENCE LEADERSHIP ACADEMY; 5) EXPAND TARGETED MESSAGING AROUND RESILIENCY STRATEGIES; 6) CREATE NEW, ACCESSIBLE COOLING CENTERS AND MULTI-DISCIPLINARY PARTNERSHIPS THAT LEVERAGE THE RESOURCES AND COMMUNICATION CHANNELS OF CBOS, COUNTY DEPARTMENTS, AND MUNICIPALITIES IN AREAS AT GREATEST RISK FOR CLIMATE IMPACTS; 7) MONITOR SURVEILLANCE DATA, INFORMING ADAPTION ACTION PLANS THROUGH QUALITATIVE EVALUATION STRATEGIES THROUGHOUT THE PROJECT; AND 8) INCREASE CROSS-COLLABORATION, COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT, AND RESOURCE SHARING BETWEEN COUNTY DEPARTMENTS AND CBOS TO ENSURE THAT ADAPTATION ACTIVITIES ARE EFFECTIVE. THE CSC IS COMMITTED TO ADDRESSING SOCIETAL CHALLENGES POSED BY A CHANGING CLIMATE AND RACIAL INEQUITIES, BUILDING COMMUNITY CAPACITY, AND LEVERAGING RESOURCES TO ENABLE RESILIENCY AND HEALING AMONG THE MOST VULNERABLE COMMUNITIES IN SCC.

BRACE - BACKGROUNDARIZONA (AZ) EXPERIENCES A VARIETY OF CLIMATE-SENSITIVE HAZARDS THAT IMPACT HEALTH. THERE WERE 145 DAYS OVER 100 F IN 2020 IN PHOENIX (NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE, 2021). AZ?S ENVIRONMENTAL PUBLIC HEALTH TRACKING (EPHT) PROGRAM REPORTED 14,428 HEAT-RELATED EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT (ED) VISITS & 1,537 HEAT-RELATED DEATHS. A RECORD 520 DEATHS OCCURRED IN 2020. WILDFIRES ARE ALSO A SIGNIFICANT ISSUE IN AZ AND ARE AFFECTED BY SEVERE DROUGHT CONDITIONS IN THE STATE. AZ?S AIR QUALITY IS ALSO AN ISSUE DUE TO DUST STORMS AND POLLUTION. SEVEN 100,000+ ACRE FIRES OCCURED FROM 2002-2020 ACCORDING TO THE NATIONAL INTERAGENCY FIRE STATISTICS. ADDITIONALLY, IN 2019 ALONE THERE WERE 25,201 ASTHMA ED VISITS FOR ARIZONA RESIDENTS. THE AIM OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ENHANCE THE ARIZONA CLIMATE AND HEALTH PROGRAM (CHP) PREVIOUSLY FUNDED BY THE CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION (CDC) CLIMATE-READY STATES AND CITIES INITIATIVE (CRSCI) BY UPDATING THE WORK DONE PREVIOUSLY ON THE BRACE STEPS WITH NEW INFORMATION SUPPORTED BY THE COMPENDIUM. NEW INFORMATION WILL HELP WITH ACCEPTABILITY AND FEASIBILITY OF ADAPTATION PROJECTS WITH PARTNERS. ADHS AIMS TO COLLABORATE WITH ARIZONA STATE UNIVERSITY (ASU) CLIMATE SCIENTISTS AND UNIVERSITY OF ARIZONA (UOFA) COLLEGE OF PUBLIC HEALTH EPIDEMIOLOGISTS TO START ADAPTATIONS IN ARIZONA?S TWO LARGEST COUNTY POPULATIONS, MARICOPA AND PIMA COUNTIES. THE FIRST PROJECT WILL BE ON EVALUATING COOLING CENTERS TO PROTECT VULNERABLE POPULATIONS FROM THE HEAT AND THE SECOND PROJECT BEING TO DEVELOP NEW COUNTY CLIMATE AND HEALTH STRATEGIC PLANS. THE GOAL IN FUTURE YEARS AND WITH OPTIONAL COMPONENTS IS TO EXPAND THESE EFFORTS TO MORE COUNTIES IN THE STATE. YEAR 1 WILL FOCUS ON HELPING ENGAGE THESE PARTNERS AND WORK TO RAISE CLIMATE AS A PRIORITY THROUGHOUT THE STATE WITH YEARS 2-5 FOCUSING ON MAINTENANCE AND EXPANSION OF EFFORTS. WITH THE SUPPORT OF THE COMPENDIUM, THE PROGRAM AIMS TO UPDATE THE OUTDATED 2017 AZ CLIMATE AND HEALTH ADAP TATION PLAN AND AID LOCAL PUBLIC HEALTH AGENCIES IN AZ. THE ARIZONA CHP IS ALSO APPLYING FOR OPTIONAL COMPONENTS A, B, AND C TO HELP SUPPORT THE CORE COMPONENT EFFORTS. MORE DETAILS ARE AVAILABLE IN EACH OPTIONAL COMPONENT'S NARRATIVE. THIS PROJECT NARRATIVE  AND SUPPORTING GRANT DOCUMENTS WILL HELP DESCRIBE THE STRATEGIC PLAN AND OPERATIONAL CAPACITY TO SUCCESSFULLY ACCOMPLISH THE GOALS OF THE NOFO.

BUILDING RESILIENCE AGAINST CLIMATE EFFECTS: IMPLEMENTING AND EVALUATING ADAPTATION STRATEGIES THAT PROTECT AND PROMOTE HUMAN HEALTH - THIS IS A COMPETITIVE 5 YEAR GRANT APPLICATION FOR THE CONTINUATION OF NORTH CAROLINA'S DECADE-LONG CDC-FUNDED PROGRAM TO ADDRESS THE COMPOUND CLIMATE CHANGE HAZARDS OF EXTREME HEAT, WILDFIRE IMPAIRED AIR QUALITY, AND FLOODING EXTREME EVENTS. SPECIFICALLY THE GRANT FOCUSES ON HEAT-RELATED ILLNESS, ASTHMA, AND OTHER CONDITIONS THAT MAY BE EXACERBATED BY THESE INCREASING THREATS FROM CLIMATE CHANGE. THIS FUNDING WILL SUPPORT COMMUNITY-BASED IMPLEMENTATION OF PREVENTION EFFORTS IN THE SANDHILLS REGION OF SOUTHEASTERN NORTH CAROLINA, AN AREA OF THE STATE AT INCREASED RISK FROM THESE COMPOUND CLIMATE HAZARDS. FUNDS WILL BE PASSED THROUGH TO LOCAL HEALTH DEPARTMENTS, PRIVATE NON-PROFITS, AND OTHER STATE AGENCIES TO COMPLETE THE CLIMATE AND HEALTH WORK. THE FUNDING SUPPORTS PREPAREDNESS EFFORTS, AS WELL AS REACHING HISTORICALLY RESILIENT POPULATIONS EXPERIENCING VULNERABILITIES. THE PURPOSE OF THIS APPLICATION IS TO DEVELOP, IMPLEMENT, AND EVALUATE ADAPTION ACTIONS THAT WILL BUILD CLIMATE RESILIENCE IN NORTH CAROLINA. THE OVERARCHING STRATEGIES INCLUDE: 1) COLLABORATING WITH STAKEHOLDERS TO CREATE A CLIMATE IMPACT COMPENDIUM THAT INCLUDES DATA ON LOCAL CLIMATE PROJECTIONS, HEALTH EFFECTS, SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH, AND CURRENT ADAPTIVE CAPACITY; 2) PLANNING, IMPLEMENTING, AND EVALUATING ADAPTATION ACTIONS THAT RESPOND TO THE THREATS IDENTIFIED IN THE CLIMATE IMPACT COMPENDIUM; AND 3) USING AND DISSEMINATING OF EVALUATION RESULTS TO IMPROVE ADAPTATION ACTIONS AND ENHANCE UNDERSTANDING OF EFFECTIVE CLIMATE RESILIENCE ADAPTATIONS. NORTH CAROLINA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES ALSO PROPOSES TO DEVELOP A CLEAN AIR STARTS EARLY PROGRAM, A CLIMATE MITIGATION APPROACH TO IMPROVING HEALTH IN CHILD CARE CENTERS, AND TO LAUNCH A DATA MODERNIZATION EFFORT THAT BUILDS ON COVID-19 DATA PIPELINES TO CREATE A CLIMATE AND HEALTH DASHBOARD.

NORTH CAROLINA BUILDING RESILIENT ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH CAPACITY PROGRAM - NORTH CAROLINA IS SITUATED IN THE MID-ATLANTIC REGION AND EXTENDS INTO THE OCEAN, PUTTING IT IN THE PATH OF HURRICANES AND TROPICAL STORMS. OVER THE PAST DECADE, NORTH CAROLINA HAS EXPERIENCED 14 MAJOR DISASTER DECLARATIONS WITH FIVE OF THOSE DECLARATIONS A RESULT OF HURRICANES OR TROPICAL STORMS AND ANOTHER FIVE AS A RESULT OF WIDESPREAD FLOODING DUE TO SEVERE STORMS. THESE NATURAL DISASTERS MAGNIFY THE ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH CHALLENGES IN OUR STATE, AS RESIDENTS STRUGGLE TO MAINTAIN SAFE DRINKING WATER, FUNCTIONING SEPTIC SYSTEMS AND HEALTHY HOMES THAT ARE FREE OF MOISTURE DAMAGE AND MOLD. WATER DAMAGE FROM HURRICANE FLORENCE AND TROPICAL STORM MICHAEL PERSISTS TO THIS DATE, POSING A HEALTH RISK TO ALL THOSE WHO LIVE OR WORK IN BUILDINGS IMPACTED BY THE STORMS. THE NORTH CAROLINA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES (NCDHHS) BUILDING RESILIENT ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH CAPACITY (BREHC) PROGRAM IS PROPOSING TO IMPROVE THE CAPACITY OF NCDHHS TO IDENTIFY, DETECT AND PREVENT EXPOSURES TO ENVIRONMENTAL HAZARDS. BREHC WILL ADDRESS EH HAZARDS WITHIN NORTH CAROLINA TO IMPROVE CHILDREN'S HEALTH, MINORITY HEALTH AND RURAL HEALTH. THIS PROPOSAL CONSISTS OF THREE COMPONENTS; 1) COMPONENT A – STRENGTHENING CORE CAPACITY TO USE EH DATA IN NC, 2) COMPONENT B1 – STRENGTHENING DATA CAPACITY TO IMPROVE ACCESS TO SAFE DRINKING WATER FROM PRIVATE WELLS IN NC AND 3) COMPONENT C1 – FORTIFYING EH RESILIENCE IN RESPONSE TO NATURAL DISASTERS. WITHIN EACH COMPONENT, STAFF WILL WORK ON (1) STRENGTHENING EH DATA USE AND INFORMATICS CAPACITY, (2) IDENTIFYING, PREVENTING AND CONTROLLING EH HAZARDS, AND (3) ASSESSING EH INTERVENTION EFFECTIVENESS AND IMPACT. BREHC WILL IMPLEMENT THE FOLLOWING ACTIVITIES TO IMPROVE EH IN NORTH CAROLINA.  THROUGH THIS FUNDING OPPORTUNITY BREHC WILL ADDRESS, PREVENT, AND CONTROL EH HAZARDS ASSOCIATED WITH PRIVATE WELLS AND NATURAL DISASTERS. BREHC STAFF WILL IMPLEMENT TRAININGS TO STRENGTHEN THE CAPABILITY OF EH WORKFORCE TO IDENTIFY, PREVENT, AND CONTROL EH HAZARDS. BREHC STAFF WILL WORK IN CROSS-SECTOR COLLABORATIONS TO IMPLEMENT AND ASSESS INTERVENTIONS TO ADDRESS PRIORITY EH HAZARDS. BREHC WILL WORK TO REDUCE EH HAZARDS USING DATA-DRIVEN DECISIONS AND INTERVENTIONS. THIS WILL RESULT IN IMPROVED ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS AND COMMUNITY HEALTH STATUS WHILE DEMONSTRATING THE VALUE AND IMPORTANCE OF EH PROGRAM SERVICES AND INTERVENTIONS.
